Award.AwardTitle: Elliptical Radon Transforms in Image Reconstruction
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator of this project and his collaborator study elliptical Radon transforms (ERT), which play an important role in bi-static models of various imaging modalities such as near-field ultrasound tomography, synthetic aperture radar, geophysical exploration imaging, and sonar. Bi-static data acquisition geometries involve separate emitter and receiver to image a medium using signals such as acoustic or electromagnetic waves. This approach offers several advantages. In the case of radar imaging the receivers are passive; hence separating their motion from the active emitters allows receivers alone to be flown in an unsafe environment. In sonar, data collection involves the receivers towed behind the boat transmitting the sound source. In ultrasound tomography separate emitter and receiver can provide data sets, for example, of high angular resolution. Assuming constant speed of wave propagation in the medium, the mathematical model for all these modalities is expressed through the ERT defined by integrals of an unknown function over ellipsoids or ellipses. The investigators develop image reconstruction techniques for several imaging modalities based on such elliptical Radon transforms. The principal mathematical problems they address include: development of microlocal analysis of ERT in various practically important data acquisition geometries, development of exact and approximate inversion formulas and algorithms for ERT, description of injectivity sets, and range characterization of ERT, i.e. the characterization of consistency conditions for the data for the aforementioned imaging modalities. The investigators test the results of their research in laboratory ultrasound experiments performed by their collaborators in radiology and biomedical engineering.

The principal investigator and his collaborator solve image reconstruction problems that are of great importance in several fields including ultrasonic reflectivity imaging in medicine, geophysical exploration, sonar and synthetic aperture radar imaging. Many of these problems have similar mathematical representation, and the investigators develop solutions as well as derive numerical algorithms for such problems. The goals and novel results of this project provide a positive impact on healthcare technologies (e.g. early detection of cancer), national security (e.g. improved radar systems), economics (e.g. improved geophysical exploration, or industrial nondestructive testing), and for many other fields of modern life, where the use of remote sensing and imaging has become an indispensable tool. The investigators work with their collaborators to test the results of their research in laboratory ultrasound experiments. The investigators advise and mentor students on research topics directly related to this proposal, and train future specialists of the field. They are committed to graduate and undergraduate teaching and engage students from underrepresented groups in the form of introductory workshops, tutorials and short courses. The investigators broadly disseminate the results of the project through publications in selected scientific journals and presentations at conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the investigators studied the properties of the elliptical Radon transforms (ERTs) and the mathematical problems related to ERT arising in various applications of image reconstruction. They also studied and compared with ERT, several other related integral transforms, including the spherical Radon transform (SRT), the V-line (or broken-ray) Radon transform (VRT) and the conical Radon transform (CRT).

 

ERTs play a significant role in bi-static models of near-field ultrasound tomography, synthetic aperture radar (SAR), geophysical exploration imaging, and sonar. These modalities use an emitter, which sends signals (e.g. acoustic or electromagnetic waves), and a receiver, which records the reflections of the sent signals from various objects in the medium. The collected data is then used to create an image of the unknown medium. Assuming constant speed of wave propagation in the medium, the mathematical model for all these modalities is expressed through the ERT defined by integrals of an unknown function over ellipsoids or ellipses. SRT can be considered as a simpler case of ERT that corresponds to the mono-static setups of aforementioned imaging modalities. In this case the same device plays the role of the emitter and the receiver of signals. VRT and CRT naturally appear in the mathematical models of single-scattering optical tomography (SSOT) and several imaging techniques that use the effects of Compton scattering. Various scanners based on these techniques are often used in medicine, homeland security, astronomy, and industrial testing.

 

ERT, VRT, and CRT are very scarcely studied objects in mathematics; hence all of the original results obtained in this project can have substantial impact not only in integral geometry, but also on the development of associated imaging techniques. From the point of view of mathematical discoveries, the investigators and their collaborators have done a thorough study of microlocal properties of ERT in various practically important data acquisition geometries, established injectivity results and derived several inversion formulas for ERT in such geometries. They have also developed and implemented numerical algorithms for inversion of ERT, studied their stability, robustness and accuracy.  A few inversion formulas have been also developed and numerically tested for VRT and CRT.

 

The work of the investigators and their collaborators on ERT has also had significant implications for the associated imaging modalities. In the context of SAR imaging, it was shown that while true images are recovered in a standard image reconstruction algorithm, artifacts (false features) can appear as well. Therefore it is of interest to understand the nature of artifacts, measure their strength in comparison to the true images, and describe ways of collecting data that would help to avoid them. For a practically relevant SAR problem (for instance imaging objects when vertical walls are present near them) the investigators achieved a complete characterization of the artifacts and their strengths. The work showed that for such an imaging scenario, the image reconstruction algorithm introduces three sets of artifacts in addition to the true image. In a different work, the investigators and their collaborators studied several approaches to design practically relevant ways of collecting data so that at least some of the artifacts are suppressed. Their work shows that in doing so, new artifacts are created in unexpected ways. In addition, they worked on comparing two frequently used ways of collecting data in seismic and sonar imaging; the common-offset and common midpoint acquisition geometries.
